input: Patient presents with eye symptoms including redness, swelling, and tearing. Symptoms began approximately 2 days ago after playing soccer.1. Diagnosis: Corneal abrasion Justification: Trauma from playing soccer can cause superficial corneal scratches, leading to redness, tearing, and discomfort, which present acutely within 2 days.  2. Diagnosis: Conjunctivitis Justification: Common cause of redness and tearing; however, less likely here given recent trauma, but cannot be excluded, especially if irritation persists.  3. Diagnosis: Subconjunctival hemorrhage Justification: Sudden eye trauma can cause ruptured small vessels leading to bleeding under conjunctiva, presenting as localized swelling and redness; typically benign.  4. Diagnosis: Traumatic hyphema Justification: Eye trauma may result in blood accumulation in the anterior chamber, causing redness and swelling; needs urgent assessment but less common with minimal symptoms described.  5. Diagnosis: Allergic conjunctivitis Justification: Can cause redness, tearing, and swelling, but less likely post-trauma; unlikely unless pre-existing allergy history.  6. Diagnosis: Uveitis (anterior) Justification: Inflammatory response possibly triggered by trauma; presents with redness and tearing but usually with pain and photophobia.  7. Diagnosis: Globe rupture Justification: Serious ocular trauma presenting with redness, swelling, and possibly decreased visual acuity; red flags require urgent evaluation.  8. Diagnosis: Intraocular foreign body Justification: Penetrating trauma from soccer may introduce foreign material into eye, causing swelling and redness; always a concern with eye trauma.  9. Diagnosis: Orbital cellulitis Justification: Less likely without systemic signs, but trauma can lead to secondary infection resulting in swelling and redness.  10. Diagnosis: Infectious keratitis Justification: Usually associated with contact lens use or infection rather than trauma alone; less likely in this scenario.  STOP HERE.
